DIV1.P: A MATCH AT MID-NIGHT. A Pleasant Comoedie: As it hath beene Acted by the Children of the Revells.
LONDON: Printed by Aug. Mathewes, for William Sheares, and are to be sold at his Shop in Brittaines Bursse. 1633.

LIST.ITEM: Iarvis, the VViddowes Husband disguised like her servant.

DIV1.HEAD: A MATCH AT MID-NIGHT.
Actus Primus. Scaena Prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter as making themselues ready, Tim Blood-hound, and Sim the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: GOod morrow Master Tim.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Morrow Sim, my father stirring Sim?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Not yet I thinke, he heard some ill newes of your Brother Alexander last night, that will make him lye an houre extraordinarie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Hum, I am sorry the old man should lye by the hower, but oh, these wicked Elder Brothers, that sweare refuse them, and drinke nothing but wicked Sacke, when wee sweare nothing but niggers noggers, make a meale of a bloate Herring, water it with foure shillings Beere, and then sweare wee have dined as well as my Lord Maior.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Here was Goody Finne the fish-woman fetcht home her Ring last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Yee should have put her money by her selfe, for feare of wronging of the whole heape.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: So I did fir and washt it first in two waters.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: All these petty pavvnes sirrah, my Father committs to to my managing, to instruct me in this craft, that when he dyes, the common-wealth may wanta good member.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Nay, you are curst as much as he already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh Brother, 'tis well you are up.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Why, vvhy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Now you shall see the dainty Widdow, the sweete Widdow, the delicate Widdovv, that to morrow morning must bee our Mother in Lavv.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What the Widdow Nagge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Yes, yes, she that dwells in Blacke-fryers, next to the signe of the Foole laughing at a feather.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Shee, shee, good Brother make your selfe handsome, for my father will bring her hither presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Niggers noggers, I thought hee had bene sicke and had not bene up Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Why so did I too, but it seemes the Widdow tooke him at a better hand, and rais'd him so much the sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim
SP.P: While I tye my Band, prethee stroke up my fore-toppe a little, Niggers, and I had but dreamed of this an houre before I wak't, I wood have put on my Sunday cloathes, 'mailes my shoos are as pale as the checke of a stewd Pander, a clout, a clout Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: More hast, the vvorse speed, here's ne're a clout now.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Whats that lyes by the bookes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: This 'tis a Sumners coate.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Prithee lends a sleeve of that, had a Noble on't last night, and neuer paid me my Bill money.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter old Bloodhond, the Widdow, her maid, and man.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Looke, looke vpon, and ready, all ready Widdow is, he is in some deepe discourse with Sim, concerning moneyes out to one or another.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Has he sayd his prayers sit?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Praver before providence, when did yee know any thrive, and swell tha uses it, hee's a chip o'th old blocke, I exercise him in the trade of thrift, by turning him to all the petty pawnes, If they come to me, I tell 'em I haue given over Brokering, moy∣ling for mucke and trash, and that I meane to live a life Monasticke, a praying life, pull out the tayle of Cressus from my pocket, and sweare 'tis cal'd Charities looking glasse, or an exhortation to for∣sake the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Dainty Hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: But let a fine foole that's well feathered come, and with∣all good meate, I have a friend it may be, that may compassionate his wants, Ile tell ye an olde Saw for't over my chimnie yonder, a poore man seeme to him that's poore, and prayes thee for to lend, but tell the prodigall (not quite spent) thou woo't procure a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Trust me a thristy sawe.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Many will have vertuous admonitions on their walles, but not a piece in their coffers, give mee these vvittie politique sawes, and indeed my house is furnisht vvith no other.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Hovv happy shall I be to vved such vvisedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Shall bed it, shall bed it wench, shalt ha't by infusion, looke, looke. Enter a Smith.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Save ye Master Tim.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Who's this, goodman fyle the black-smith, I thought'had beene our old collier: did you goe to bed vvith that durty face goodman fyle?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And rise vvith it too sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What have you bumming out there goodman fyle?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A vice sir, that I would faine bee furnisht vvith a little money upon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Why how vvill you doe to vvorke then goodman fyle?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This is my spare vice, not that I live by.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Hum, yee did not buy this spare vice of a leane Courtier, did yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No sir, of a fat Cooke, that strain'd of a Smith for's rent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Oh hard hearted man of grease.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Sim, vve must doo't sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Ha thrifty whorsonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: And vvhat wood serue your turne goodman fyle?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A Noble Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What upon a spare vice to lend a Noble?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Why sir, for ten groats you may make your selfe drunke, and so buy a vice outright for halfe the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: That is no noble vice I assure ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: How long vvood y have it!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: But a fortnight, 'tis to buy stuffe I protest sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Looke ye being a neighbour, and borne one for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Ha villaine, shalt have al.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: There is five shillings uppon't, which at the fortnights end goodman Fyle you must make five shillings sixe pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: How sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Nay and it were not to doe you a curtesie—

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Ha Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: And then I had forgot three pence for my Bill, so there is foure pence, and nine pence, which you are to tender backe, five shillings sixe pence, goodman Fyle at the end of the fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Well and it were not for earnest necessitie, hay boyes, I come, I come, you blacke rascalls, let the Cans goe round.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Sim, because the man's an honest man, I pray lay up his Vice, as safe as it were your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: And if hee misse his day, and forfeit, it shall bee yours and your heires for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: What, disbursing money boy? here is thy mother in law

SP.SPEAKER: Clowne
SP.P: Your nose drops, 'will spoyle her ruffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Pray forsooth—what's a clcke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.P: Oh fie upon him Mistresse, I thought he had begunne to aske you blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Peace, vveele have more oa't. Walk's towards him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I wonnot kisse indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim
SP.P: And he wonnot, here are those that will forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Get ye in you Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I hope yee will Sir? I was bred in Ireland where the wo∣men beginne the salutation.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I wonnot kisse truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Indeed you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Wood my girdle may breake if I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I have a minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Niggers noggers I wonnot.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Nay nay, novv his great oath's past, ther's no talke on't, ke him nere the worse, ther's an old savv sort,
SP.L: A kisse first, next the feeling sence,
Cracke say the purse strings, out flie the penee.
SP.P: But he can talke though, whose Boy are you Tim?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Your boy forsooth Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Can ye turne and vvind a penny Tim.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Better then yourselfe forsooth father.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: You have look't in the Church booke late, bovv olde are you Tim?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Tvvo and tvventy yeeres, three moneths', three dayes, and three quarters of an houre, forsooth Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: He has Arethmaticke.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: And Grammer too, vvhat's Latine for your head Tim?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Caput.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: But vvhat for the head of a blocke?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Caput blockhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Doe ye heare, your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Aura.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Your eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Occules.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: That's for one eye, vvhat's Latine for tvvo.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Occulies, occulies.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: An admirable accidentall Gramarian I protest sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: This boy shall have all, I have an elder rogue that sucks and dravves mee, a saverne Accademian: one that protests to Whores, and shires vvith High-vvay lavvyers; an arrant unclari∣fied Rogue, that drinkes nothing but vvicked Sacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Here's a Gentleman would speake with you,

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Looke, looke, novv hee's come for more money.

SP.SPEAKER: Widdow.
SP.P: A very hopefull house to match into wench, the Fa∣ther a Knave, one sonne a drunkard, and tother a foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: O monster Father, looke if hee bee not drunke, the very sight of him makes me long for a cup of sixe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Pray Father, pray to God to blesse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Looke, looke, takes his brother for his Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim:
SP.P: Alas Sir, when the drink's in, the wit's out, and none but wise children know their owne Fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim:
SP.P: Why I am none of your Father, brother, I am Tim, doe ye know Tim.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Yes, umph—for a coxecombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: How wild he lookes: good sir weele take our leaves.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P:
Shalt not goe faith Widdow: you Cheater Rogue, must I ha my friends frighted out my house by you, looke heele steale
nothing to feast his Bawdes, get ye out sirrah, there are Con∣stables, Beadles, whips, and the Colledge of extravaging, E∣clipt Bridewell yee Rogue, yee Rogue there is, there is—marke that.

SP.SPEAKER: Alexander.
SP.P: Can you send mee a Marke vpon this Ring sir, and there set it downe in your Booke, and vmph—marke that.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Ile have no stolne Rings, pickt out of pockets, or taken upon the way, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Ile give you an old saw for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: There's a Rogue mocks his Father, sirrah, get 'ye gone, Sim, goe let loose the Mastiffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Alas sir, heele teare and pull out your sonnes throate.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Better pul't out, then a halter stretch't, away out of my doores rogue, I defie thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Must you be my Mother in Law?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: So your father sayes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: You see the worst of your eldest sonne, I abuse no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: The Rogue will fall upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: I will tell ye an old sawe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Pray let's heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: An old man is a bed full of bones,
and who can it denie,
By whom (vmph) a yong wench lyes and greanes,
for better companie.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Did yee ever heare such a Rascall? come come, let's leaue him: Ile goe buy thy wedding Ring presently, y'are best bee gone sirrah: I am going for the Constable, I and one of the Church-wardens, and now I thinke on't, hee shall pay five shil∣lings to the poore for being drunke, twelve pence shall goe into the boxe, and tother foure, my partner and weele share betwixt us, there's a new path to thrist wench, wee must live, wee must live girle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And at last die for altogether.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: 'Tis a Dyamond.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Youle be at the fountaine after dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: White, twill runne boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P:
Here's a noble now, and Ile bring you tother as I come
by to the Taverne, but Ile make you sweare, I shall drinke no∣thing but small Betre.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Niggers naggers thou shalt not, there's thine owne oath for thee, thou shalt eate nothing and thou woo't, but a poacht spider, and driue it downe with sirrup of Toads. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Ah, prithee Sim bid the maid eate my breakefast her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Has turn'd his stomacke, for all the World like a Puritanes, at the sight of a surplesse, but your breakefast shall bee devoured by a stomacke of a stronger constitution I war∣rant you. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Captaine Carvegut, and Lieuetenant Bottome.

SP.SPEAKER: Captaine.
SP.P: No Game abroad this morning, this Coxecombe Parke, I thinke bee past the best, I have knowne the time the bottome twixt these hilles has beene better fledg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Looke out Captaine, there's matter of imployment at foote o'th hill.

SP.SPEAKER: Captaine.
SP.P: A businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Yes, and hopefull, there's a morning bird, his flight it seemes for London, hee hallowes and sings sweetely, prithee let us goe and put him out of tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Thee and I haue Cratchets in our pates, and thou know∣est two Crotchets make one quaver, he shall shake fort. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: Did her not see her true Loves,
As her came from London,
Oh, if her saw not her fine prave Loves,
Randall is quite undone,
SP.P:
Well, was neuer mortall man in Wales, coo'd have wagd pra∣ver, finers, and nimblers, then Randals have done, to get service in Londons: whoope, vvhere vvas her novv, just upon a pridge of stone, between the legs of a couple of pretty hils, but no more nere mountaines in Wales, then Clim of the Cloughes bowe, to her Cozen Davids Harpe, and now her prattle of Davie, I thinke yonder come prancing down the hils from Kingstone a coupl of her
tother cozens Saint Nicholas Clarks. the morning was so red as an egge, and the place ferry full of dangers, perills, and bloody busi∣nesses by reports: augh her swords was trawne, God plesse us and her cozen Hercules was not stand against too, which shall her take if they take Randalls, will rippe Randals cutts out, and then Ran∣dals shall see Pawles steeples no more, therefore her will goe di∣rectly vnder the pridge, here was but standing to knees in little fine coole faire waters, and becat if her have Randalls out, her shall come and fetch Randalls and her will, were her nineteene Nicholas Clearkes. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Which way tooke hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: On streight I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Then we should see him man, hee was just in mine eye when we were at foot o'th hill, and to my thinking stood here loo∣king towards us upon the bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: So thought I, but with the cloud of dust wee rais'd about us, with the speed our horses made: it seemes we lost him, how I could stampe and bite my horses eares off.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Let's spurre towards Coomb house, he strucke that way, sure hee's not upon the Roade.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: 'Sfoot if wee misse him, how shall vvee keepe our word with Sander Bloodhound in Fleetstreete after dinner at the Foun∣taine, hee's out of cash, and thou knowest by Cutters Law, wee are bound to relieve one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Let's scowre towards Coomb house, but if we misse him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: N matter, dost see yonder Barne o'th left hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: What of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: At the West end, I tore a piece of board out,
And stuft in close amongst the straw, a bagge
Of a hundred pound at least, all in round shillings:
Which I made my last nights purchase for a Lawyer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Dost know the place to fetch it againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: The torne board is my land marke, if we misse this,
We make for that, and whilst that lasts—oh London,
Thou Labyrinth that puzlest strictest search,
Convenient Innes of Court, for highvvay Lavvyers,
Hovv vvith rich wine, Tobacco, and svveet Wenches,
we will canvase thy darke case.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Away, let's spurre. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Spurre did her call her, have made Randals stand without pootes, in ferry pittifull pickles, but her will run as nimbles to Londons, as Creyhound after Rabbits, and yet now her remember what her Cozens talkt, was some wiser and some too, Randals heard talke of Parne upon left hand, and a prave bag with hundred pounds in round shil∣lings Cod plesse us, and yonder was Parnes and upon left hands too, now here was questions, & demands to be made, why Randals should not rob them would rob Randals, her will goe to parnes, plucke away pords, pull out paggs, and shew her cozen a round paire of heeles, with aule her round sillings, marke her now. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: The Rogue rise right, and has out stript us this was staying in Kingstone with our unlucky Hostesse, that must be dandled, and made drunke next her heart, she made us slip the very Creame o'th morning, if any thing stand augward, a woman's at one end on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Come, we have a hundred pieces goodyet in the Barne, they shall last us, and Saunder a moneths mirth at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Oh these sweete hundred pieces, how I will kisse ye, and hugge ye with that zeale a Vsurer does his bastard money, when hee comes from Church, wert not for them, where were our hopes, but come, they shall bee sure to thunder in the Taverns, I but now, just now I see pottle pots throwne downe the stayres, just like Serieants and Yeomen, one i'th necke of another.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Delicate vision. Exeunt. Ent. Ran.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P:
Her have got her pag and aule by the hand, and her had ferrily thought in conscience, had not bin so ma∣ny round sillings in whole worlds but in Wales, twas time to supply her store, her had but thirteene pence halfe
penny in awle the worlds, and that her have left in her little vvhite purse, with a rope her sound py the parne, just in the place her had this: Randals will bee no serving mans now, her will buy er prave Parrells, prave Swords, prave Taggers, and praue eathers, and goe a wooing to prave comely pretty mads, rb Randalls, becat and her were ten dozens of cozns, Randals rob her, marke her now. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: A plague of Friday mornings, the unfortunate day in the whole weeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Was ever the like sate, 'sfoote when I put it in I was so wary, though it were midnight, that I watcht till a cloud had mask't the Moone, for feare shee should have seen't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Oh lucke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: A Gale of wind did but creepe ore the bottome, and because I heard things stirre, I staied, 'twas twelvescore past mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: The pottle pots will sleepe in peace to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: And the sweete clinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: The clattering of pipes.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: The Spanish fumes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: The more wine boy, the nimble aon, non sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: All to night will be nothing, come wee must shift, sfoot what a vvitty rogue 'tvvas tave, this faire thirteen pence halfepenny, and this old halter, intimating atly.
SP.L: Had the hang-man met us three, by these presages,
Here had bin his worke, and here his wages.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Come, come, vve must make friends. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: There sirrah, there's his bond, runne into the Strand, sxe weekes the allow Chandler fetcht my hundred mark, ent him to set him up, and to buy greate, this is his day, Ile have his bones fo' se, so pray tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim
SP.P: But are a Chandlers ones worth so much Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Out Coxecombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Worth so much, I know my Master will make dice on them, then 'tis but letting Master Alexander carry them next Christmas to the Temple, he'le make a hundred marks a night of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Masse that's true.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: And runne to Master Eare-lacks the informer, in Theeving lane, and aske him what he has done in my busi∣nesse he gets aboundance, and if he carry my cause with one false oath, he shall have Moll, he vvill take her with a little, are yee gone Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: No forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: As yee come by Temple-barre, make a steppe to'th Divell.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: To the Divell father?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: My Master meanes the signe of the Divell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: And he cannot hurt ye foole, ther's a Saint holds him by the nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Sniggers, what does the Divell and a Saint both in a signe?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: What a question's that, what does my Master, and his prayer booke a Sunday both in a pew?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Well, well, ye Gipsy, what do wee both in a pew?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood
SP.P: Why make a faire shew, and the Divell and the Saint does no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Blod.
SP.P: 'are witty, y'are witty, cal to the man o'th house, bid him send in the bottles of wine to night, they will be at hand i'th morning,—will ye runne sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: To the devill as fast I can Sir, the world shall know who's sonne I am. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood
SP.L: Let me see now, for a posie for the Ring:
Never an end of an old saw, 'tis a quicke Widdow Sim,
And vvood have a vvitty posie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim
SP.P: If she be quick, shee's with child, vvhosoever got it you must father it, so that you come o'th nicke, forthe wid∣dow's quicke, there's a witty posie for you quick Widow▪

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: No, no, Ile have one shall savour of, of a sawe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Why then 'twill smell of the painted cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Let me see, a Widdovv vvitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Is pastime pretty, put in that for the sports sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: No, no, I can make the sport, then an old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Then will she answere, if you cannot a yonger can,
And looke, looke sir, now I ta ke of the yonger,
Yonder's Ancient Young come over againe, that
Mrgaged sixtie pound Per annum before he went,
I am deceived if he come not a day after the Faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Mine Alminacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: A prayer booke sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: A prayer booke for devote beggers I hate, looke I beseech thee, Fortune now befriend mee, and I will call the plaguy whore in, let me see, sixe moneths.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, tis he certaine, this is a businesse must not bee slackened sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Looke I beseech thee, wee shall have oat meale in our pottage sixe weekes after.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Foure dayes too late Sim, foure dayes too late Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Plummes in our pudding a Sunday, plummes in our pudding.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Master bloodhound as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: You are a stranger Sir, you shall be witnesse, I shall be rayl'd at else, they vvill call me devill, I pray you hovv many moneths from the first of May, to the sixt of November following?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Sixe moneths and foure dayes just.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: I aske, because the last first of May, a noble gentle∣man, one Antient Young.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I am the man sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: My spectacles Sim, look Sim, is this Ancient Yong?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Tvvas Antient Young sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: And is't not Ancient Young?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: No sir, you have made him a young Ancient

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Oh Sim, a Chayre, I know him now, but I shall not live to tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How fare yee sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: The better for you, he thanks you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Sicke, sicke, exceeding sicke,

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: O'th suddaine, strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: A qualme of threescore yeeres come over his sto∣macke, nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: That you beloved, you, who of all men i'th world, my poore heart doted on, whom I loved better then Father, Mother, Brother, Sister, Vncles, Aunts, what wood yee have, that you should stay foure dayes too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I have your money ready,
And sir, I hope your old love to my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Nay, nay, I am Noble, fellow, very Noble, a very rocke of friendship, but, but, I had a house and barne burnd downe to the ground, since you were here.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: How burn'd aske Sim?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: By fier, sir, by fier.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: To build vp which, for I am a poore man, a poore man, I was forced by course of Law to enter upon your Land, and so for lesse money then you had of me, I was faine to sell it to another, that by foure dayes stay, a man should lose his blood, our liuings, our blood, ô my heart, ô ny head.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Pray take it not so hamons, weele goe to him. Ile buy it againe of him, he wonnot be too cruell.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: A dogge, a very dog, there is more mercy in a paire of unbrib'd Bailiffes, to shunne all such solicitings, he's rid to Yorke, a very cut-throate Rogue, but Ile send to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: A honest olde man, how it mooves him, this was my negligence, good Sim convay him into some vvarmer roome, and I pray, how ever Fortune, shee that gives ever with the dexteritie she takes, shall please to fashion out my sufferings, yet for his sake, my deceas'd Father, the long friend of your heart, in your health, keepe me happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Oh right honest young man Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Sir, Blood. Have I don't well?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: The deu'll himselfe coud not have don't better.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P:
I tell thee an old sawe sirrah, hee that dissembles in wealth shall not want, they say doomes day is comming, but thinke you not an't, this will make the pot seeth Sim,
good Sir talke no more, my mouth runnes over, Sleepe, wake, worthy begger, worthy indeed to be one, and am one worthily—how fine it is to wanton without afflicti∣on, I must looke out for Fortunes, over againe, no, I have money here, and 'tis the curse of merit, not to worke, when shee has money: there was a handsome Widdow, whose vvild ma jalous husband died at Sea, let mee see, I am neere Black-fryers, Ile have oe start at her, or else—

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Bloodound, Daughter Mol, with a bowle of beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: By my troth tis he Captaine Yongs soone, I have lved him even with languishings, ever since I was a girle but should I know it, I should run mad sure, what handsom Gentlemen travaire and manners makes, my Father begun to ye Sir, in a cup of finall Beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How does he pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Pretty well now Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Mas 'tis small indeed—youle pledg me?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Pray will ye tell me one thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: What is't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant
SP.P: Which is smaller, this Beere, or your maidenhead?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: the Beere a great eale Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I in qualitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: But not in quantitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: No?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Let me try, and Ile tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Will you tell me one thing before you try?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Which is smaller, this Beere or your wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: O the Beere, the Beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: In qualitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, in quantitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Why then I pray keepe your quantitie of your wit, from the quality of my maydenhead, and yee shall find my maydenhead more then your wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: A witty maydenhead by this hand.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus. 2. Scaena 1.
DIV1.STAGE: A Table set out. Enter two servants, Iarvis and Iohn, as to cover it for dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Is my Mistresse ready for dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Yes, if dinner be ready for my Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Halfe an houre agoe man.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: But prithe sir, is't for certaine, for yet it cannot sink into my head, that she is to be married to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Troth, shee makes little preparation, but it may be she wood be wedded, as sh wood be bedded, privatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Bedded call ye it, and she be bedded no better then heele bed her, she may lie antaliz'd and eate wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Pox on him, they say hee's the arrantst . i er, we shall never live good day with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Wel, and she be sipt by threescore and ten, may she live sixescore and eleven, and repent twelve times a that's once an houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Set meate o'th board. Enter Wid.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Yes. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Why doe's your fellow grumble so?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: I doe not know.
They say y'are to marry one that will feede us.
With horse-plummes, instead of Beefe and Cabidge.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And are you grieu'd at that?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: No, but my friends are.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What friends are grieu'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: My guts.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: So it seemes, you begon Clowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Yes, and shall conclude Coxecombe, and I be fed with herring bones, 'sfooe, I say no more, but if wee de want as much bread of our dany allowance, as wood dine a Sparrow, or as much drinke as wood foxe a Flie, I know what I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And what doe ye know sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Why, that there goes but a paire of sheetes, a pro∣moter, and a knave, if you know more, take your choice of either.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Tis well sir, set on dinner.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Iohn with a Rabbit in one hand, and a dish of ogges in another, and the Mayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: O Mistresse, yonder's the mad gallant, Master A∣lexander Bloodhound entred into the Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Ye should have kept him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.P: Alas, nere a wench in towne could doo't hee's so nimble, I had no sooner opened the doore, but hee thrust in ere I was aware. Enter Alex.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: And how does my little handsome daintie, deli∣cate, welfavoured, streight, and comely delicious bewitch∣ing Widdow.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: 'Sfoote here's one runs division before the Fidlers.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Sir, this is no seasonable time of visite.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Tis pudding time wench, pudding time, and a daintie time, dinner time my nimble eyd witty one, woot be married to morrovv sirrah. sets to table.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Shee will be mad to morrovv sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: What, art thou a fortune teller.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: A chip of the same blocke, a foole Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Good foole, give me a cup of coole Beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: your Master a coole cup of Beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Pish, I spoke to the foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: I thought y'had brought the foole with you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Foole, 'tis my man, shalt sit i'faith wench,

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: For once I be as merry as you are mad, and learne fashions, I am set you see Sir, but you must pardon Sir our rudenesse, Fridayes fare for my selfe, a dish of egges and a Rabbet, I lookt for no stranger faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Strange, mine's a good face ifaith, prithee Busse.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Why here's one comes to the businesse now.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Sirrah, woot have the old fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Your Father, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I tell thee thou shalt not, no, no, I have such—

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: There's but one raw bit Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Thy Iester sure shall have a coate.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Let it be of your owne cut Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Nay, nay, nay, two to one is extremitie—but as was telling thee, I have such a husband for thee, so knowing, so discreete, so sprightly, fill a Cup of Claret, so; Admira∣bly, in desires so excellently, Admirably deserving, that an old man, fie, fie, prethe—ha to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: The man's mad sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Mad, by this hand, a witty Gallant.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Prithee peace, shalt heare a Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid,
SP.L: What copes-mate's this trow, who let him is?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: By this light, a fellow of an excellent breeding.
He came unbidden, and brought his stoole with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Looke Mistresse, how they stare one at another?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Yes, and swell like a couple of gib'd Cats, met both by chance i'th darke, in an old Carret.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Look, looke, now ther's no feare of the wild beasts, they have forgot their spleenes, and looke prettily, they fall to their pasture, I had thought they had bin angry, and they are hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Are they none of Duke Humsreyes furies, doe you thinke, that they devis'd this plot in Pauls to get a dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Time may produce as strange a trueth.
Let's note them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: Her loved her once, her loved her no more,
Saint Tauis so well as her loved her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Another Barre, this is the Cooke-maids leaving, ope the doore, and this is the daintiest dish shee has sent in, a Widgia in Welch sawce—pray lets make a merry day on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: What doe her keepe open house, had her heard her was Widdovves that dwelt here, are you Widdowes good wons?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: I want a husband Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P:
Augle Randalls comes in very good times, you
keep Ordinaries her thinke, what have you set a cat before gallants there?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: They will eate him for the second course—these are suters to my Mistris sure, things that she sleights, set your feere boldly in, Widowes are not caught as maids kisse, faintly, but as Mastiffes fight, valiantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Is her so, I pray bid her Mistresse observe Ran∣dals for valours, and prave adventures?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Some Beere.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Let them want nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Here VVidow.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: I thanke you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Some Wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Here is Wine for you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.L: Randals will not be outprav'd I warrant her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Here VVidow.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: I thanke you too Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: Sounds some Metheglings here.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: What does he call for?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Here are some egges for you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.L: Egges man, some Metheglings, the wine of Wales.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Troth sir here's none i'th house, pray make a ver∣sue of necessitie, and drinke to her in this glasse of Claret.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Well, because her will make a great deales of ne∣cessities of vertues, marke with what a grace Randals will drinke to her Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.L: He makes at you forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Let him come, I have ever an English vertue to put by a welch.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: O noble Widdowes, her heart was full of woes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No noble Welchman, her heart was in her hose.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: 'Sounds, was that her manners to take away Randalls cups?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: No, it shewed scurvy.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Tak't you at worst then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Whelpe of the Devill, thou shalt see thy Sire for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn. Iar.
SP.L: Gentlemen what meane ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Randals.
SP.P:
Let her come, let her come, Randals will
redeeme reputations her warrant her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Redeeme your wit sir, first for you Sir, you are a stranger, and see you,—but you, fie Master Bloodhound.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha, Bloodhound, good sir let me speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.P: Sounds, what doe Randals amongst ploodhounds, good Widdowes lend her an eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Ancient Young, how false our memories have plaid through long discontinuance, but why met here man, is Mars so bad a pay-master, that our Ancients fight under Cupids Banner?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Faith this was but a sudden start begotten from distraction of some fortunes, I pursue this Widow but for want of wiser worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: The Welchman labours at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: A payre of a hundred of seepes, thirtie prave Cowes, and twelue dozen of Runts.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Twelve dozen of Goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.L: Give her but another harke?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: He has the morgage still, and I have a handsome sister, doe but meet at the Fountaine in Fleetestreete after dinner, ô I will reade thee a History of happines, and thou shalt thanke me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: A, reade all's well, or vveapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A word Iarvis?

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.P: Oh prave VViddowes, her vvill meete her there, he know her times and her seasons, her warrant her, Ran∣dalls will make these prave Gallants hang her selfes in those garters of willow Garlands apout her pates, marke her now, and remember. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Adiew sweet widdow, for my ordinary—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Twas not so much worth Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: You meane, 'tvvas worth more then, and that's another handsomely beg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: You conclude women cunning beggers then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, and men good benefactors, my best wishes wait on so sweet a Mistris—will ye walke? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Ile follow yee, woo't thinke on't soone at night, or not at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: I wood not have my wishes wrong'd, if I should bring it about handsomely, you can be honest?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Can, do'st conclude me a'satt in cheate?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: No, a smooth Gallant sir, doe not you faile to bee here soone at nine, still provided, you wil be honest, if I con∣vey you not under her bed, throvv me a top o'th Tester, and say mee o o'th way like a rusty Bilboe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Enough, drinke that, fare el, Widdovv, Fate, the Destinies, and the three ill favoured Sisters, have concluded the meanes, and vvhen I am thy Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: I shalbe your vvife.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Doe but remember these crosse Capers, then yee pitter sweete one?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Till then adiew ye bitter sweete one.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: This dinner would have shewed better in bed-lane, and shee a tother side, holdeth her whole nest of suters play, vvhat Art decks the darke Labyrinth of a womans heart. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.L: Marry old Earelacke, is my Father mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: They are both a concluding on't yonder, to mor∣row's the day, one vvedding dinner must serve both mar∣riages.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Oh Sim, the Ancient, the delicate Ancient there's a man, and thou talk'st of a man, a good face & sparkling eye, a strenght body, a delicate hand, a cleane legge and foote, ah sweete Sim, there's a man worth, Maidenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: But I say, Master Eare-lacke the old man, a foote like a Beare, a legge like a bed-staffe, a hand like a hatchet, an eye like a pigge, and a face like a vvter Pigme, there's a man for a Maydenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Oh looke, looke, oh alas what shall I doe vvith him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P:
VVhat, vvhy vvhat shall fifteene doe vuith sixtie and tvvelve, make a screene of him, stand next the fier,
whilest you sit behind him, and keep a friends lips warm, many a wench vvod be glad of such a fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Your oath strucke it dead then? ô my sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Five hundred deepe of your side itaith father.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Mol, come hither Mol, I hope Sim has discouer'd the project?

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: And to morrovv must bee the day Mol, both of a day, one dinner shall serve, we may have store of little ones, vve must save for our familie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Good Sir, what rashnesse was parent to this mad∣nesse, marry an old man—Eare-lacke the Informer?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Madnesse—y'are a vvhore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Is she a vvhore Sim?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: She must be your vvise, I tell—

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: An arrant vhore, to refuse Master Innocent Eare∣lacke of Rogue-land, that for his dwelling, next that hee doth Informe novv and then against enormities, and hath bin blancketted, it may be pump't in's time: yet the vvorld knovves, he dos't not out of need, hee's of mighty meanes, but takes delight now and then to trot up and dovvne, to a∣void Idlenesse, you vvhore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Pray Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: This wound vvants oyle, good sir in al my pathes
I will make you my guide, I vvas only startled,
And vvith the suddennesse of the vvord marriage
In that I knevv, that this deserving Gentleman
And I, had never so much conference,
VVhereby this coale of Paphs, by the Rhethoricke
Of his love-stealing heart, Captivating Language,
Might be blovvne into a flame.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Does she take Tobacco Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: No, no, man, here are out of ballads,
She has all the Garland of good vvill by heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Snailes she may sing me asleepe a nights then Sim

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: VVhy, right Sir, and then 'tis but tickling you o'th forehead vvith her heeles, you are avvake againe, and ne're the vvorse man.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll
SP.L: Is he but five yeeres older then your selfe sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Nay, I want a weeke and three dayes of that too.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Ile tell thee an old sawe for't girle, old, say he be, old blads are best, young hearts are neuer old.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Ah Hay.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Gold is great Glee, gold begets rest, what fault is found in Gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I will answere presently Sir, with another Sawe.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Let's ha't, lets ha'te.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: Marke Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Young, say she be yong, young Mutton's sweete, content is above Gold, if like an old Cocke he with yong Mutton meetes, he feedes like a Cuckold.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: A very pretty pithy one, I protest, looke and Moll dee not laugh, shalt have a payre of gloves for thee, what leather do'st love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Calfe Sir, shp's too simple for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis a witty notable knave, he should never serve me else.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: My Mistresse remembers her love, and requests you would endure her so much to your patience, as to reade that.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Love letters, love lies, do'st marke Sim, these Women are violent, Sim, whilst I reade the lie, doe you rayle to him upon the Brewer, sweare has deceiv'd us, and saue a cup of Beere by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: I will save you a cup at that rate fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: I can make thee a hundred a yeere joynture wench, at the first indeed, I began vvith petty businesses wench, and here I pickt, and there I pickt, but novv I runne through none but things of Value.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Sir, many thoughts trouble me, and your words carry such vveight, that I will chuse a time, when I have nothing else to doe, to thinke on 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: By my troth, she talkes the vvittiliest, and I wood understand her.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Oh nimble, nimble Widdow, I am sorry wee haue no better friends, but pray commend me, tho in a blunt dry Commendations at the time and place appointed, I wonnot faile, I know she has a nest of suters, and wo'd car∣ry't close, because she feares surprisall.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: What newes Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Shalt lie there all night sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: VVas that the first nevves I heard on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: I must meete a friend i'th darke soone, let me see, we lovers are all a little mad, doe you and Moll take a turne or two i'th garden, whilest Sim and I goe up into the Gar∣ret and device, the guesse come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: He's a little mad, and I had best hang him upon the crosse beame in the Garret. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: Come Mol, come Molkin, wee'le even to the Ca∣mamile bed, and talke of houshold stuffe, and bee sure thou remembrest a Trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Please ye goe before Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: Nay, an old Ape has an old eye, I shall goe before, and thou vvoo't shevv mee a Love-tricke, and locke mee into the Garden, butterflies, I will come discreetely be∣hind Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Out upon him, what a suiter have I got, I am sorry you are so bad an Archer sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.L: VVhy Bird, why Bird?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: VVhy, to shoote at Buts, vvhen you shou'd prick-shafts, short shooting vvill loose ye the game, I a you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eare.
SP.P: Her minde runnes sure upon a Fletcher, or a Bow∣yer, hovvsoeuer, Ile informe against both the Fletcher, for taking vvhole money for piec't arrovves, the Bowyer for horning the head men of his Parish, and taking money for his paines. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter in the Taverne, Alex. the Captaine, Lieutenant, Sue Shortheeles, a whore, Mistresse Cooke, a Bawde.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Some rich Canarie boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Anon, anon Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Possible us cheated of a hundred pices, A hansome halter, and the Hangmans wages pop' in the place, what an acute vvitnesse we have in vvickednesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Tis done, and handsomely you.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Here's a pottle of rich Cannary, and a quart of neate Clarret Gentlemen, and there's a Gentleman belovv, he sayes he is your Brother, Master Bloodhound, he appoin∣ted to meete you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: The expected thing that bought the Bristovv stone.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Send him up prithee, remember hovv it must bee carryed?

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd
SP.P: I am her Grandmother, forgt not that by any meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: And pray remember that you doe not mump as if you were chvving Bacon, and spoile all.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: I vvarrant yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: And harke.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Are these th company sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, but those I k not, thee are not they, Ile stay i'th next roome till my company come.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: VVhere you please Sir, pray follovv me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: I heare him comming up gingerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Oh hee tramples upon the bosome of a Taverne vvith that dexterity, as your Lavvyers Clearkes doe to VVestminster Hal upon a durty day vvith a paire of vvhite silke stockings, Brother Tim, vvhy novv y'are a man of your vvord I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Nay I love to be as good as my say, see brother, looke, there's the rest or your money upon the Ring, I can∣not spend a penny, for I have ne're a penny left, vvhat are these, vvhat are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Gallants of note and qualitie, hee that fits taking
Tobacco is a Captaine, Captaine Carve-gut.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim
SP.L: He vvill not make a Capon of me, vvill ee.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Are you not my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hee that powres out that sparkling sprightly
Claret, is a Lieutenant vnder him, Lieutenant B.
He was a Srgant first.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Of the Poultry, or of Woodstreete.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Of the Poultry, of a Woodcock:
A Sergnt in the Field, a man of blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: I'le take my leaue brother, I am in g ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: That delicate sweet young Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Fough this Tobacco.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: That beares the bsh of ing vpon her cheekes, whoseeyes are like a payre of ing Twies.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Sh lookes ust vpon e.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I thinke you are in hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: No, no, no pray:

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Whose lips are beds of Roses, betwixt which
There steales a breath sweeter thn Indian Spices.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Sweeter then Ginger.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: But then to touch thse lips—you stay too long sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Pish I tell you, I doe no, I know my time, pray what's her name?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: But 'tis descended from the cian steeme, the great tributie L her e, th cit on is her reuerent Granham.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Niggers I haue read of her in the Mirrr of Kaighthood.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Co they shall know you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Nay brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I say they shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Let me goe downe and wash my face first.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.L: ce is a ne face my brother Gentle.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Sir, you are victoriously welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: That word has 'ne conqued me.

SP.SPEAKER: Li.
SP.L: I desire to ki your hand Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Indeed but you shall not Sir, I went out early, and forgot to wash e'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Bd.
SP.L: Precious Doil.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P:
Sir, I shall call it efie if you shall to
vouchsae to pledge me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: What is't brother foure or sixe?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: oure or sixe, 'tis rich Canary, it came from be∣yond the Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I wi doe no curtesie at this time Sir, yet for one cup I care not, because it comes from byond the Seas.
SP.L: I thinke 'tis Out-landish win.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.L: Looke how it glides.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Now truly the Gentleman drinkes as like one Ma∣ster Widgen a kinsman of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Pox on yee heiding.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I ha' heard of that Widgin, I ha' beene taken for him, and now I thinke on't, A cup of this is better then our foure shilling Beere at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: You must drink another Sir, you drunk to no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Is it the law, that if a man drinks to no body, hee must drinke againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: I, I, I. Fill his glasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Why, then I will drinke to no body once more, because I will drinke againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Did I not tell yee. More wine there Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.L: This Pageant's worth the seeing by this hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Mee thinks this glasse was better then the to'ther Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Oh Sir, the deeper the sweeter euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Doe yee thinke so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Euer that when yee drinke to no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Why then I pray giue me tother cup that I may drinke to some body.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.L: I haue not drunke yet sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Againe ye Witch? drinke to the young Gentle∣womn.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Mistris Lindabrides.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.L: Thanks most ingenious sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Shee's a little shame fac'd, the deeper the sweeter forooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Pox on ye for a Coxcombe.

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: I'th next roome I haue seene and heard all.—Oh noble ouldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Here Boyes, giue vs some more wine. There's hundred Markes Gallants. 'Tis your owne. And doe but let mee beare on Office amongst yee. I know as great a matter has beene done for as small a summe. Pray let mee follow the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Well, for once take vp the money, Giue mee a cup of Sacke. And giue me your hand sir, and because our Flemish Corporall was lately choakt at Delph with a Flap∣dragon. Beare you his name and place, and be henceforth call'd Corporall Codshead. Let the health goe round.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Round. And this goe not round. Some wine there Tapster. Is there ne're a Tapster i'th house?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: My worthy friend, thou art Master of thy word, Gentlemen 'tis Auntient Young, y'are Souldiers, come come, saue cap, complement in cup. Prithee sit downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Are you a Captaine sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: And you a Lieutenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I pray where serued you last?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Why, at the battell of Prague.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Vnder what Colonell. In what Regiment?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Why, lt me see: but come in company: let's sit sir. True Souldiers scorne vnnecessary discourse, especially in Tauernes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Tis true, true Souldiers do: but you are Tauern-rats.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Prithee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Foule food that lyes all day vndisgested,
Vpon the queasie stomack of some Tauerne,
And are pewed out at midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Corporall Codsheads health sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: In thy face foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: This is a cruell Antient.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: ee are but the wormes of worth,
The sonnes of shame and basenesse,
That in a Taverne dares out-sit the Sunne,
And rather then a Whore shall part unpledg'd,
You'le pawne your soules for a superfluous cup,
Though ye cast it into the reckoning,
The true souldier, who is all o're, a History of man,
Noble, and Valiant, Wisedome is the mould,
In which he casts his Actions, such a discreete temperance
Doth dayly decke his doings, that by his modesty,
He is guest the sonne of merit, and by his mildnesse
Is beleeved Valiant, goe, and build no more
These yrie Castles of hatcht fame, which fooles
Onely admire and feare you for, the wise-man
Derides and jeeres ye puffes really of
Vertue and Vallor? (These faire twinnes
That are borne, breath and die together) then
Youle no more be cal'd butterflies, but men:
Thinke on't, and pay your reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Shall we suffer this Saunder?

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.L: I must goe after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.P: Kill him, and there be no more men in Christen∣dome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.P: I know my Sister loves him, and hee sweares hee loves her,—and by this hand, it shall goe hard if hee have her not, smocke and all, brave excellent man, with what a strength of zeale wee admire that goodnesse in another, which we cannot call our owne. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Hee's a dead man I warrant him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: But where's our Corporal, Corporall, Corporall?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Well, here's your Corporall, and you lookes out can be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.P: Looke and he have not inconst himselfe in a wood∣den Castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Is he gone that cal'd us butter-flies?

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: Yes, yes, has taken wing, and your Brother's gone after him, to fight with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P:
Thats well, he cannot in conscience but doe us the curtesie and kill him for us, come gallants, what shall wee doe? Ile never goe home to go to bed with my guts full of shillings beere, when I may replenish them with
Sacke,—Hay, now am I as lusty, me thinkes wee two have blew eards, is there nere a wench to be had? Drawer bring us up impossibilities, an honest Whore, and a conscionable reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Why here's all fier, wit, where he will or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.P: Ah whore, ô tempting, handsome Sir, thinke of a rich Wife rather.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Tempting handsome Sir, shee is not married is she Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: A woodcock spring'd, let us but keepe him in this bachavalian mist till morning, and 'tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Tempting handsome Sir, I have knowne a wo∣man of handsome tempting fortunes, throw her selfe away upon a handsome tempting Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Harke you sir, if shee had, and coo'd bee tempted too't, have you a mind to marry: woo'd ye marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Oh, and a man were so, worthy tempting Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Give me but a piece from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: And when will you give it me againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Pray give mee but a piece from you, Ile pay this reckning intoth' argaine, and if I have not a tricke to make it your owne, Ile give you ten for't—here's my witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: There 'tis, send thee good lucke with't, and goe drunke to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.P: Do not you be too rash, for she observes you, and is infinitely affected to good breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I wonnot speake I tell you, till you hold up your finger, or fall a vvhistling.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap
SP.P: Come, weele pay at Barre, and to the Miter in Bredstreete, weele make a mad night on't, please ye sweete Ladies but to walke into Bredstreete, this gentleman has a fooish sleight supper, and he most ingenuously professes, it would appeare to him, the Meridian Altitude of his de∣sired happinesse, but to have the table deckt with a paire of perfections, so exquisitely refulgent.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: He talks all sacke, and he wil drinke no small Beere:

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd
SP.L: Pray leade, and he shall follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.L: Blesse mine eyes, my heart is ful of changes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Oh, is it so, I have heard there be more changes in a womans heart in an houre, then can be rung up on sixe bells, seven dayes, well go thy wayes, little do'st thou think how thou shalt be betrayed, within this foure and twenty houres, thou shalt be mine owne Wife, flesh and blood, by Father and Mother, ô tempting hansome Sir.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus. 3. Scaena. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: But sirrah, can'st tell what my Mistresse meanes to doe with her suiters?

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.P: Nay, nay, I know not, but there is one of them I am sure worth looking after.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Which is he, I prithee?

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.L: Oh Iohn, Master Randall, Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: The Welchman.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: The witty man, the pretty man, the singing man, he has the dantiest dittie, so full of pith, so full of spirit, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Ditties, they are the ends of old Ballets.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Old ends, I am sure they are new beginnings with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Here comes my Mistresse:

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Who was that knokt at' Gate?

SP.SPEAKER: Lar.
SP.L: Why your welch wooer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.P: Alas, the sight on's eyes enough to singe my little May denhead, I shall never be able to endure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: When high King Henry, second rul'd this land,
the couple of her name,
Besides her Queene, was teerely lou'd,
a faire and Princely—Widdowes,
SP.P: Harke you Widdowes, Randals was disturb'd in cogitati∣ens, about Lands, Ploughs, and Cheese presses in Wales, and becat her have forgot where her, and her meete soone at pright darke Evenings.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Why on the Change, in the Dutch walkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Oh haw, have her—but Randals was talke no Ducth, pray meete her in the Welch walke, was no Welch walke there?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Fie, no, there are no Welch Merchants there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ran.
SP.P: Mas, was ferry true, was aule Shentlemen in Wales, her never saw her Shamber-maid, pray where was her Shamber-maid?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Taken up i'th Kitchin Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Can her make wedding pedd pravely for Randals, and Widdowes?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Pray tell him Iarvis where she can or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Sir, not to delay, but to debellitate the strength of your Active apprehension of my Mistresse favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.L: Was ferry good woords.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Hearke in your eare, shee will have her nest fea∣thered with no Brittish breed.

SP.SPEAKER: Randall.
SP.P: Zounds, was not Prittish so good as English?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Yes, Where ther's Wisedome, Witt, and Valour, but as amongst our English, wee may have one Foole, a Knave, a Coxecombe, and a Coward, shee bid mee tell yee, shee has seene such wonders come out of Wales in one shirt, y'are an Asse, and sheele have none of you

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Augh, S. Tauie, Owen Morgan, and aule her Co∣sins, was Widdow her selfe ay so?

SP.SPEAKER: VVid.
SP.P: Good sir, let every circumstance make up one an∣swere, take it with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iaruis.
SP.P: And the Rmane answere is, the English goose Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P:
Sounds, her vvas kill novv, gog, and gogmagog, a whole dozen of shiants, make oole of Randals, Randalls vvas vvisht to as prave match as widows vvas, know one Mary Bloodhound,
was ha aule, when her father kicke up heeles, and becat though her never saw her, her will send her Love letters presently, get her good wills, and goe to shurch and marry, and her were eight and thirtie, two hundred and nine and fifty widdowes, marke her novv.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: He pelts as he goes pittifully.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid:
SP.L: Where's Mary?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Pray goe to Algate, to my Sempstris for my rue, I must use it say too morrow, did yee bid her hollow it just in the French fashion cut?

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.L: Yes forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Twas well, we have no other proofe in use, that we are English, if wee doe not Zany them, let Iohn goe with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.L: Yes forsooth:

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: But pray forsooth, how doe you meane to dispose of your suitors?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Shall I tell thee, for this thou hast given him this cure, and he is past care, for old Bloodbound the Saw-mong∣er, I writ to him, to meet me soone at ten in the darke, vpon the change, and if I come not by ten, he should stay while twelue, intimating something mystically, that to avoid sur∣prizalls of other Rivals, I meane to goe from thence with him to lye at his house all night, and goe to Church with him i'th morning, when my meaning is onely knvery, to make my selfe merry, and let him coole his heeles there till morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: And now have I a whimsey, newly jumpt into the coll of ingenious apprehensive, to sawce him daintisy, that for that, what thinke yee of the Gentleman that brought a a stoole with him out of the Hall, and sate downe at dinner with ye in the parler?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: They say hee's an Ancient, but I affect not his Cllours.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: But what say ye to the mad victorious Alexander?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: A wild mad Roarer, a trouble not worth minding.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Hee will minde you ere morning: troth Mistris There waytes a Gentleman i'th next roome, that hath a long time loued you, and has watcht for such an houre, when all was out of doores, to tell you so; and none being within but you and I, hee desires you would heare him speake, and there's an end on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: What is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: An honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: How know yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: Why, he told me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And why were you such a foole to take his owne word?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Because all the witte I had cood get no bodies else.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: A Knaue will euer tell you he's an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: But an honest man will neuer tell you hee's a knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Well sir, your Mistresse dares looke vpon the ho∣nest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: And the honest man dares looke vpon my Mi∣stresse. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: 'Tis the roughest bluntest Fellow.
SP.P: Yet when I take young Bloodhound to a retired collection of scattered iudgement, which often lyes disioynted, with the confused distraction of so many: Mee thinks he dwells in my opinion, a right ingenious spirit, vailde meerely with the vanity of youth and wildnesse: he lookes mee thinks like one that could retract himselfe from his mad starts, and when he pleased turne tame: his hansome wildnesse mee thinkes becomes him, could hee keepe it bounded in Thrift and Temperance: but downe these thoughts, my resolue rests here in priuate,—But from a foole, a Miser, and a man too iealous for a little sweetnesse loue, Cupid de∣fend me.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter like a Gentleman very braue with Iaruis cloathes in's hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: And to a Widdow wife,
Nobly liberall, and discreetely Credulous,
Cupid hath sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Pray prooue as you appeare a Gentleman. Why Iaruis?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Looke yee here's Iaruis haangs by Geometry, and here's the Gentleman. For lesse I am not that afarre off ta∣ken with the Sainted praises of your wealthy beauty, your person, wisedome, modesty, and all that can make woman gracious, in this habite sought and obtayn'd your ser∣uice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: For heauens sake what's your intent?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: I loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Pray keepe off.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: I wood keepe from you. Had my desires bodies
How I cood beate them into better fashion,
And teach them Temperance, For I rid to finde you;
And at a meeting amongst many Dames,
I saw you first: Oh how your taking eyes,
Those actiues sparkling sweet discouered twins,
In their strong captiuating motion, told me
The story of your heart, a 100 Cupids
Me thought sate playing on that payre of Christails,
Carrying to the swiftnesse of conetous Fancie,
The very letters we spell loue with.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Fie. Fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: I haue strucke her to the heart, through my face
Apparelled with this field of grauity,
The neglected roughnesse of a Souldiers dart.
SP.P: These diamond pointed eyes but hither through, and you will see a young spring on't, but question times fayre ones.
They 'le confesse, tho with a blush they haue often found good wine at an old bush. My blood is young, and full of amorous heates, which but brancht out into these lusty veynes,
SP.L: Wood play, and dally, and in wanton Turnings
Wood teach you strange constructions.
SP.P: Let time and place then vvith Loues old friend oportunity instruct you to be wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: 'Las Sir, where learned you to catch occasions thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Of a Lawyers Clarke wench, that with sixe such Catches, leapt in fiue yeares from his Deske to his Coach drawne with foure horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: Doe yee meane marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.P: Marriage a cloying meate, marry who thou woot to make a shew to shrowd thee from the stormes round headed opinion, that swayes all the world, may let fall on thee. Me Cozen? thou shalt call once in a moneth, or so: I'le reade false Letters from a farre distant Vncle, insert his commendations to thee, hug thy beleeuing husband into a payre of hansome hornes. Looke vpon him with one eye, and winke vpon thee with tother. Woodst haue any more?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: The returne of Seruants, or some friendly visite will intercept vs now: reassume your habit, and bee but Iaruis till no morrow morning, I now by the potent truth of friendship, I will giue you plenty of cause to confesse I loue you truly, and strongly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: 'are in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.L: On my life serious, let this kisse seale it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iar.
SP.L: The softest vvax euer seal'd bawdy businesse.
SP.P: Now for old Bloodbound, I will meet you vpon the Change Sir, with a blinde bargaine, and then helpe your sonne to a good penny-worth: this night shall be all mirth, a Mistris of delight. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Bloodhound, Earelacke with Letters, Sim, and Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Nay, nay, nay, marke what followes, I must bring her home'th darke, turne her vp to bed, and heere she goes to Church: my Cloake sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: 'Tis a very darke night sir, you will not haue a cloake for the rayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: I am going to steale the Widdow from I know not how many.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Nay, then I let your cloake for the raine alone, and fetch you a cloake for your knaverie. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: To bed, to bed—good sonne, what Sim I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: I charge yee let not one bee vp ith'house, but your selfe, after the clocke strikes ten, nor a light bee stirring, Moll, Tricke up the greene bed-chamber very daintiy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim
SP.L: I shall Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: And well remembred Moll, the keyes of my Compting house, are in the left pocket of my hose above i'th wicker chayre, looke to them and haue a care of the blacke boxe there I have often told thee of, looke to that as to thy Maydenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: I shall sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Pray for me all, pray for me all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.L: Have you left out any thing for supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: Out Rogue shall not I bee at infinite expence to morrow, fast too night, and pray for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: An old diuell in a greasie Sattin doublet, keepe you company.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.L: Ha, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I say, the Sattin doublet you will weare too mor∣row, will be the best in the company sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Blood.
SP.P: That's true, thats true, I come Widdow, I come VVench.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Oh sweete Sim, what shall I doe to morrow, to morrow must be the day, the dolefull day, the dismall day, alas Sim, what dost thou thinke in thy con-science I shall do with an old man?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Nay, y'are well enough served, you know how your rother not an hoe agoe, lay at you o have the Ancient, one that your eethe'ne water at, and yet you cry, I cannot love him, I wonnot have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: I coo'd willingly marry him, if I might doe no∣thing but looke on him all day, where he might not see me, but to he with him, alas I shalbe undone the first night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: That's true, how will you goe to bed else, but re∣member hee is a man of Warre, an Ancient, you are his co∣lours, now vvhen he has nimbly display'd ye, and hansomly foulded ye up against the next fight, then we shall have you cry, ô sweete Sim, I had beene undone, if I had not beene vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Nay, and then the olde fellow would mumble mee to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: A bed, a Bawd with two teeth would not mumble Bacon, so then hee so sparing you, shall weare nothing, but from the Brokers at second hand, when being an Ancients wife, you shalbe sure to flourish.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Prithee goe in and busie the old man with a piece of Reynard the Foxe, that he may not disturbe us, for at this houre I expect Ancient Yong, and my Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Well, I leave you to the managing of Ancient Yong, while I goe in and flappe the olde man i'th mouth with a Foxe tayle. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Look, look, & he have not brought him just upon the minute, ô sweete silken Ancient, my minde givesme, thee and I shall dance the shaking of the sheetes together.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Now, you Mistresse fig-aile, she Wind come about yet, I ha brought the Gentleman, doe not you tll him now, you had rather have his roome then his compa∣ny, and so shew your breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Novv fie upon you, by this light y'are the wic∣ked'st fellow, my Brother but abuses yu, pray Sir goe o∣ver againe, yo'ue a hansome spying wi, you may send more trueth over in one of your wll pen'd pamphlets, then all the vveekely nevves we buy for our penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Poxe on't, Ile stay no loger.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Sfoote thou shalt stay longer, we'le stay her heart her guts out.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Ha, ha, how will you doe for a sister then?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Prithee Moll doe, doe but looke upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: s, when I ha no better obiect.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: What canst thou see in him thou unhansome ous thing, that merrits not above thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: What woo'd I give to kisse him?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Has hee not a hansome body, streight leg'd, a good face.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Yes, but his lips looke as if they were as hard as his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Foote, shall try that presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Y'are basely sir conditioned,—Pagh.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Why, doe you it?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Yee may goe by this light, he kisses sweetly.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Doe bt stay a ite Moll, prithe Moll, thou knowest y Father has wrong'd him; make him amens and marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Sweet M. Spedall spare your busie breath,
I must haue a wise man, or else none.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: And is not he a wise man?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Because he keepes a foole company.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Why, you are now i's company.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: But birds of a feather will fly together, and you and he are seldome asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Why you young witch, call your elder brother oole; but goe thy wayes, and keepe thy may denhead till it grow more deseruedly depied, then are the olde base bootes of a halfe stewed Pander: Leade a Welch Morris with the Apes in hell amongst the little deuills,—or when thou shat lye sighing, by the side of some rich foole,—remember thou thing of threed and needles, not worth three pence halfe penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Too late I feare I ha'bene too coy, you are to be married then sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I am indeed sweet Mistresse, to a Mayd
Of excellent parentage, breeding, and beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I ha'thought of such Musitians for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: But let it not be any way distastull vnto you, that thus I tri'd you, for your brother perswaded mee to pre∣tend loue to you, that he might perceiue how your minde stood to marriage, in that (as I guesse) hee has a husband kept in store for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, I haue prouided a husband for thee Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mll.
SP.P: But I'e haue no husband of your prouiding, for alas now shall haue the old man whether I will or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: I haue such a stripling for thee, he wants one eye, and is crooked leg'd, but that was broke at Footbale.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Alas, we cannot mould men you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hee's rich, hee's rich Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Ha'him and his riches good sir, y'are to be mar∣ried in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: In earnest; why, doe yee thinke men marry as Fencers sometimes fight, in iest?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Shall I shew her Mistresse Elizabeths Letter I snatcht from thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Not, and thou louest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Goo brother let me see't, sweet brother, daity brother, hony broth.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex
SP.P: No ineed, you shall not se't, sweet sister, dainty ister, hony sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Oh good si, since so long time I haue loued you, let me not dye for your sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: The tide turnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Long time ued me?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Long re you wnt to Sea I did.
I haue loued you very long with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Thinke of Besse; thinke of Besse, 'tis the better match.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Ye wicked brother, Indeede I loue you better, then all the Besses in the world, and if to night I shift not into better fortunes, to morrow I am made the miserablest wie marriage and misery can produce.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Alas Sir, I am to mary an old man, a very old man, trust mee, I was strange in the nice timerous temper of a Ma, I knovv'tis against our sexe to say we love, but rather then to match vvith sixty and ten, threescore and ten times I woo'd tell you so, and tell them ten times over too, trueth loves not vertue with more of vertuous trueth, then I doe you, and wonnot you love me then? Weepes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: And lye vvith thee too by this hand VVench, come let us have faire weather, thou art mine, I am thine, there's an end of the businesse, this vvas but a tricke, ther's the projector.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Oh y'are a sweete brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: And now th'art my sweete Sister, I know the old man's gone to meete with an old wench that will meet vvith him, r Iarvis has no juice in's brains, and vvhile I i'th meane time, set another wheele a going at the Widowes, doe thou soone about ten, for 'tis to bee very conveniently darke, meete this Gentleman at the Nags head corner, iust against Leaden-hill, wee lie in Lime-streete, thither he shall carry thee, Accomodate thee daintily, all night with Mistris Dorothy, and marry thee i'th morning very Methodically.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: But I haue the charge of my Fathers keyes, where all his writings lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How all things jumpe in a just equivalencie, to keepe thee from the thing of threescore and ten, didst thou not see my Morgage lately there?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Stay, stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex
SP.L: A wlte devil with a red fox taile, in a black box.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol
SP.P: But yesterday my father shewed it me; & swears if I pleased him wel, it should serve to mp out my portion.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Prove thine old Dad a Prophet, bring it with thee Wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll
SP.P: But novv at's parting, hee charged me to have a care to that, as to my Maydenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Why, fine have thy Maidenhead and that into the bargaine, thy carge is perform'd, away, get thee in, forget not the houre, and you had better fight under Ancient Yongs colours, then the old Mans standard of sixty and ten. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Remember this, mad-braine.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus 4. Scaena. 1.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Suo, Tim, Captaine, and Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, Grandmother, Ile tell thee the best jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.L: Prithee chicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: Iest kether, here will bee jesting of all sides I thinke, if Iarvis keepe his word.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Sirrah, whilest thou wert sent for into the next roome, up came our second course, amongst others in a dish of blackebirds, there lay one, that I swore vvas a Wood∣cocke, you were at Table Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: That I was, and our brave mad crew, vvhich for my sake you vvere pleas'd to make vvelcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Pish, vve'le have as many more to morrow night, but still I swore twas a Woodcocke: she swore 'vvas a backe-Bird, ovv vvho shall vve be tryed by, but Serieant Sliceman, Captaine Carveguts Cozen here, a trifling vva∣ger, a matter of the reckoning was layd, the Serieant svvore tvvas a backe-Bird, I presently payd the reckoning, and she clapt of the brest presently, and svvore 'tvvas a Wood∣cocke, as if any other wood passe after the reckoning vvas paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.L: This was a pretty one I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Made sure before such a mad crew of vvitnesses, sirrah, Granham, al's agreed, Sue's—.

SP.SPEAKER: Sue.
SP.P: I you may see, hovv you men can betray poore maids.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu:
SP.P: Do you heare Corporal, yonder's Serieant Slice∣man, and the brave crew that supt with us have cal'd for three or foure gallons of wine, and are offering money.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: How, prithee Granham looke to Dab, doe you two but hold them in a talke, whilst I steale downe and pay the reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SP.L: Doo't daintily, theyl'e stay all night.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
